awd_titl_txt: Instabilities in Shape Memory Alloys and Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the most unique properties of shape memory alloys, like NiTi, is pseudoelasticity, which is the ability of the material to be deformed at room temperature to strains of a few percent and return to its unstrained configuration when unloaded. This unique characteristic is derived from a diffusionless transformation between two solid-state phases, which can be induced by changes in either stress or temperature. These characteristics are being exploited for novel structural applications in diverse fields; however, the design of shape memory structures is complicated by the: inhomogeneous deformations associated with the coexistence of the two phases during transformation, thermomechanical interactions, and significant tension-compression asymmetry. This project will use an integrated experimental-computational approach using material and structural samples to unravel these complications to enable the design and wider use of this unique class of materials. This project will progress the science of smart materials; advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare; and secure the national defense by enabling shape memory structural applications, like biomedical devices, aerospace components, damping and energy absorption, microelectromechanical systems, and morphing structures. In addition to the training of MS and PhD graduate students, the project includes undergraduate participation to attract them to research and graduate school. Outreach to K-12 students through lectures and laboratory demonstrations will be used to expand their interest in STEM subjects.

Pure bending experiments on NiTi tubes have revealed complex interactions between the prevalent material nonlinearities with structural ones that lead to localization, collapse and failure. The proposed study has three main components: (i) Experiments on NiTi tubes loaded under bending, tension, compression, pressure, and torsion are planned in order to explore the results of these interactions and the associated limit states and provide a basis for developing the necessary analytical tools. (ii) A recently developed constitutive model framework that captures the tension-compression asymmetry and the inhomogeneous deformations associated with tensile stress states will be expanded to include thermal effects. The model will be calibrated using a spectrum of uniaxial, biaxial, and thermomechanical experiments. (iii) The constitutive model will be implemented in finite element models of the structures studied, testing their ability to reproduce the measured structural behaviors and the associated limit states. This multi-pronged approach to this class of problems involving interacting material and structural instabilities should provide the necessary tools for designing shape memory structures. The fundamental nature of this investigation is expected to also impact other materials that exhibit propagating instabilities like L?ders banding in steels, foams, and wood.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The exceptional properties of pseudoelasticity and shape memory effect of shape memory alloys (SMAs) are bestowed by their unique property of undergoing phase transformation at room temperature levels by relatively modest changes in temperature or by the application of stress. In a 3-D body, the phase transformations occur sporadically, with the two phases coexisting at different locations in the object, resulting in spatially inhomogeneous deformation. Furthermore, transformations are accompanied by latent heats that locally heat or cool the body. This project, through combined experimental and analytical efforts, investigated and elucidated the effect of the inhomogeneous deformation and associated temperature transients on structures under bending (Figure 1), axial tension (Figure2), compression, internal pressure, and torsion. The experimental results, guided the development of the phenomenological constitutive modeling framework. The constitutive model, in turn, was implemented in numerical analyses of the SMA structural problems studied, capturing the interacting material and structural instabilities, and concurrently the thermal interactions with the environment, all of which are groundbreaking contributions to the field. Furthermore, the results pave the way for how to handle such mechanical instabilities and thermal interactions in SMAs and materials like ferroelectric, ferromagnetic SMAs, and other materials with localized deformations, to guide the design of smart structures and devices.

The intellectual merit of the project originated from the synergy of its three main components: (i) experiments on shape memory alloy tubes loaded under bending, tension, compression, and pressure; (ii) construction of a constitutive modeling framework that captures the unusual behaviors exhibited by shape memory alloys like the differing responses in tension versus compression, the inhomogeneous deformations associated with tensile stress states, and the strongly couple thermomechanical interactions; and (iii) the implementing of the new model in numerical simulations of the structures studied, testing their ability to reproduce the measured structural behaviors. The completion of each of these three aspects of the project required new advances in each of these facets of the science of shape memory alloys and the integration of the three is the first of its kind that has been able to predicts the detialed features of the temperature fields and localized deformation patterns that nucleate, evolve, and disappear in tubular shape memory alloys as they are thermally heated and mechanically stressed.

The broader impacts of the project include the training of 5 graduate students in the broad field of solid mechanics and in the more focused areas of smart materials and shape memory alloys. During their training these students delivered 20 presentations of their research findings at international conferences and published eight peer-reviewed journal articles with four more in preparation. Additionally, the principal investigators on the project oganized an international symposium specialized to shape memory alloy materials and structures, as well as a broader international conference in the area of theoretical and applied mechanics. These gatherings of scientists from around the world served as a conduit for the echange of ideas and the continued advance of the scientific endeavor. Finally, the broader impact of the research findings themselves stem from the intertwined theory-experiment-simulation approach that uncovered the critical role that localized deformation plays in sturctural instability, and more generally as a paradigm for the investigation of other structural systems exhibiting localized behavior and instabiltiies.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Chad M Landis
